questions.text: A researcher wants to know whether there is an association of CRP values with the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke. options.label: A
options.text: CRP has no association with risk of Ml/stroke

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in CRP increases the risk of Ml/stroke

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in CRP decreases the risk of Ml/stroke

options.text: In quintile 1, there is no risk of Ml/stroke

questions.text: A study to determine the association between maternal smoking histories from pregnant women during their antenatal visits and then subsequently assessing the birth weight of their babies soon after delivery. What type of study is this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Prospective cohort

questions.text: Which of the following is used to reduce the selection bias in a clinical trial?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Randomization

Randomisation
  • The technique where every participant will get an equal and known chance of being allocated to either the treatment group or the control group.
  • Eliminates both known and unknown confounders.
  • Selection bias is avoided by randomisation, which arises when the participants are not representative of the target population.

In a clinical trial, patients are randomly assigned to receive either a new drug or a placebo, balancing out confounding variables.

Types of Bias

Subject Bias

Investigator Bias

Analysis Bias
  • Recall bias
  • Hawthorne bias
  • Reporting bias
  • Non-response bias
  • Selection bias
    • Berksonian
    • Neyman
    • Reporting
  • Publication bias
  • Misclassification bias
  • Interviewer bias
  • Pygmalion bias
  • Golem bias (blunting of response due to demotivated observer)
  • Statistical bias

questions.text: Which of the following components are included in the Human Development Index (HDI), as per the World Health Organization (WHO)?

options.label: A
options.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living

options.label: B
options.text: Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living

options.label: C
options.text: Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living

options.label: D
options.text: Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.correct_answer: A. Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living

questions.text: Which of the options below does not constitute a component of case-control studies?
Which of the following statements is true regarding prevalence and incidence in relation to a newly introduced drug that reduces mortality but does not cure the disease?
Which of the following statements accurately describes the relationship between prevalence, incidence, and the introduction of a new drug that reduces mortality but does not provide a cure?
What does the standardized age mortality ratio indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution

options.label: B
options.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution

options.label: C
options.text: Removal of bias due to different age group population in different countries

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate age structure of different countries

questions.correct_answer: A. Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution
questions.explanation:
Types of Rate

Description

Examples

Crude Rates

Actual observed rates are calculated directly from raw data without adjustments.

Crude birth rate: Number of births / Total population * 1000

Specific Rates

Rates that focus on specific causes

Tuberculosis mortality rate: Deaths due to TB / Population at risk * 100,000

Standardised Rates

Rates are adjusted to account for differences in the composition of populations when comparing different groups or populations.

Age-standardized mortality rate.

questions.text: What is the most effective study design to demonstrate the relationship between cause and effect among the options listed below?
To study the effect of vitamin C on respiratory disease pre-post study is done. Arrange in the correct sequence. A. Select case and control. B. Matching C. Measure total exposure D. Analysis
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - ABCD

questions.text: The maternal mortality ratio is defined as?

options.label: C
options.text: Maternal Deaths per 10,000 women in reproductive age group

options.label: D
options.text: Maternal Deaths per 100,000 women in reproductive age group

questions.correct_answer: B. Maternal Deaths per 100,000 live births
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Maternal Deaths per 100,000 live births.

Indicator

Definition

Formula

Significance

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR)

Number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births

Number of maternal deaths ×100,000

—--------------------------------------

​Number of live births

Indicator of maternal health and the quality of maternal healthcare services.

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR)

Number of infant deaths (under 1 year) per 1,000 live births

​Number of infant deaths ×1,000

—-----------------------------------

Number of live births

Reflects the overall health of infants, healthcare quality, and living conditions.

Under-5 Mortality Rate (U5MR)

Probability of a child dying before age 5 per 1,000 live births

Number of under-5 deaths​ ×1,000

—------------------------------------

Number of live births

Reflects child health and effectiveness of health interventions from birth to age 5.

Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR)

Number of deaths of infants aged 0-28 days per 1,000 live births

Number of neonatal deaths​ ×1,000

—-----------------------------------

Number of live births

Measures the health of newborns and effectiveness of neonatal care and interventions.

Child Mortality Rate (CMR)

Number of deaths in children aged 1-4 per 1,000 children in this age group

Number of deaths in children aged 1-4​ ×1,000

—------------------------------------------

Total number of children aged 1-4

Reflects mortality due to preventable causes in children aged 1-4 years, indicating health and nutrition status.

Stillbirth Rate (SBR)

Number of stillbirths per 1,000 live births and stillbirths

Number of stillbirths​ ×1,000

—------------------------------------------

Number of live births + stillbirths

Reflects the quality of prenatal care and the healthcare system’s ability to prevent fetal deaths.

Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (CPR)

Percentage of women of reproductive age using contraception

Number of women using contraception ​×100

—----------------------------------------

Total number of women of reproductive age

Indicates access to and usage of family planning, helping reduce maternal and child mortality.

Total Fertility Rate (TFR)

Average number of children a woman would have over her lifetime

Sum of age-specific fertility rates

Reflects population growth and reproductive health patterns.

Life Expectancy at Birth

Average number of years a newborn is expected to live

N/A

Reflects the overall health and quality of life in a population.

questions.text: Which variable determines the disparity in disease occurrence between individuals who have been exposed and those who have not been exposed?

What type of study is it when a person collects data on lung cancer patients from government hospitals and the corresponding number of cigarette packets sold during the same time period, in order to examine the relationship between smoking and lung cancer?
The number of polio cases has been steadily declining in comparison to previous years. This pattern is known as:
questions.explanation:
Cyclical trends (Option B ruled out)

Seasonal trends (Option A ruled out)

They occur in cycles spread over short periods of time.

Cycles are associated with seasons.

Examples:

  • Measles: every 2-3 years.
  • Rubella: every 6-9 years.
  • Influenza: every 7-10 years.

Examples:

  • Measles.
  • Varicella.
  • Cerebro-spinal meningitis.
  • Upper respiratory tract infections.
  • Malaria.
  • Sunstroke.
  • Hay fever.
  • Snakebite.

questions.text: What is the recommended duration for quarantine for the 30 individuals who had contact with a 28-year-old male who is tested positive for SARS-COV-2, but are currently asymptomatic?

What is the term used to describe a disease that is typically not found in a country but is brought in from abroad, as seen in the case of a 25-year-old male who was diagnosed with the condition upon arrival at an Indian airport, leading to quarantine?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D) Exotic

Term

Definition

Examples

Epidemic (Option B ruled out)
  • Occurrence of disease clearly in excess of normal expectancy (Mean + 2SD or >80% expected frequency).
  • Occurrence of even a single case of a previously eliminated disease.
  • Occurrence of a single case of an exotic disease. (Option D)

Seasonal influenza outbreaks during winter months.

Endemic (Option A ruled out)

 
  • Constant presence of a disease within a specific population.
  • Epidemiologically linked cases in terms of time, place, or person.

Malaria in Africa, TB in India

Pandemic
  • Global spread of a disease.
  • Defined as an epidemic in a large population.
  • Requires crossing 2 continents and 2 WHO-specific regions.

HIV/AIDS, COVID-19.

Sporadic
  • They occur randomly and unpredictably, without any discernible pattern in time, location, or individual.
  • There's no epidemiological link between the cases.

Tetanus

options.label: C
options.text: Interval between Primary and secondary case

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: C. Interval between Primary and secondary case

questions.text: Arrange the steps of experimental study - Blinding Randomization Defining inclusion and exclusion criteria Statistical analysis
questions.explanation:
Step

Description

1. Defining Inclusion & Exclusion Criteria

Determines which participants are eligible for the study, ensuring a uniform population.

2. Randomization

Randomly assigns participants into groups (e.g., treatment vs. control) to eliminate selection bias.

3. Blinding

Conceals group allocation from participants, investigators, or both to reduce bias.

4. Intervention Implementation

The experimental treatment is administered while maintaining study protocols.

5. Data Collection

Outcome measures are recorded systematically for further analysis.

6. Statistical Analysis

Data is processed using statistical tests to evaluate the treatment effect.

7. Interpretation & Reporting

Findings are interpreted, conclusions are drawn, and results are published.

questions.text: In which phase of clinical trials drug dosing is determined?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Ph

questions.text: Mid-year population is the denominator in?
Blood cholesterol shown as mg/ml value is in which scale?
A gym owner observes that individuals who drink iced tea during their workouts tend to lose more weight. What is the nature of this relationship?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Indirect

Type of Association

Description

Spurious (Option A)

An association that appears to be present but is actually due to chance or an error in data.

If the gym owner's observation was spurious, it would mean that the association between iced tea consumption and weight loss is completely false and exists due to some error in observation or data collection.

Indirect (Option D)

An association in which a third variable (known as the confounding variable) causes both the predictor and the outcome.

Direct (Causal)  (Option C)

An association where the predictor directly influences the outcome.

 

If the relationship between iced tea consumption and weight loss were direct, it would mean that drinking iced tea itself leads to weight loss. However, it is unlikely that drinking iced tea alone would have a direct effect on weight loss.

a. One-to-One causal

A direct causal link between a single predictor and a single outcome.

b. Multifactorial

An association involving multiple factors contributing to the outcome.

questions.text: Which among the following cannot be studied using case-control study?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Cause to effect

Advantages

Disadvantages

  • Less time taken.
  • Inexpensive.
  • Minimal ethical problems.
  • Multiple exposure was studied.
  • Rare diseases can be studied.
  • Attrition bias not present
  • Forms the rationale for prevention and control programmes based on risk factors.
  • Selection bias.
  • Recall bias.
  • Interviewer bias.
  • Cannot measure incidence: Only provides estimation of relative risk.
  • Cannot differentiate between causes and associated factors

questions.text: A research was carried out to evaluate the impact of a treatment for a specific illness. The statistical significance of two comparable studies, A and B, was determined using interventions "X" and "Y" along with a control group, yielding p-values of 0.02 and 0.001 respectively, at a confidence level of 95%. Initial analysis suggests that the findings could be interpreted as: A. Study B is more precise than study A and intervention Y is more significant compared to Intervention X. B. Study A is more precise than study B and intervention X is more significant compared to intervention. C. Both X and Y show a significant variation, but Study B is more significant than Study A. D. Both study A and B shows a significant variation and both interventions have similar statistical significance.

options.label: A
options.text: If A, B and C are correct

options.label: B
options.text: If A and C are correct

options.label: C
options.text: If B and D are correct

options.label: D
options.text: If all (A, B, C and D) are correct

questions.correct_answer: B. If A and C are correct
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - If A and C

questions.text: Which of the following measures cannot be taken to eliminate confounding factors?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Blinding

Explanation

Randomization

 Randomly assigning participants to different groups or treatments to distribute potential confounding factors equally

Blinding

 Technique to keep participants or researchers unaware of the assigned treatment or intervention

Restriction

 Limiting the study population based on certain criteria to minimize potential confounders associated with excluded groups

Matching

 Selecting control subjects with similar characteristics to the study group to control the influence of specific confounding variables

questions.text: In India, cause of death is noted by: Sample registration system Census Death declaration & medical certificate Lay reporting

The total number of deaths was 247, with 56 deaths occurring within 28 days of life, and an additional 34 deaths occurring after 28 days but before completing the first birthday. Calculate the infant mortality rate of the area?

questions.text: Phase 1 of a clinical trial is done to test?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - S

Phase 0
  • Tested on healthy human volunteers
  • Done only in up to 10 participants
  • Microdosing (1/100th) because higher doses maybe fatal
Phase 1
  • Tested on healthy human volunteers
  • Lasts from months to years (10-100)
  • Safety and non toxic profile of the drug
  • Maximum tolerated dose of a drug ( beyond this dose, adverse effects occur)
Phase 2
  • Tested on patients
  • 50-500
  • Lasts 1-2 years
  • Effectiveness and efficacy
  • Maximum drug failure seen
Phase 3
  • Patients can be 500-3000 in number
  • This phase lasts 3-5 years
  • Comparison with existing drugs
  • Randomized controlled trials
  Drug is launched after phase 3 trials
Phase 4
  • Also tested on patients
  • Study is unending until drug removal
  • Longest phase ( at least 10-25 years)
  • Monitor long term and rare side effects
  • Post market surveillance .

Isolation

Quarantine

Cases

Healthy contact

For the period of communicability or transmissibility of disease or till the person recovers

For the longest incubation period of the disease (Absolute quarantine)

Secondary level of prevention

Primary level of prevention

questions.text: What is the relationship between incidence and prevalence in a disease with 100% mortality rate?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B- P < I

Relationship

Interpretation

Mortality > Incidence

High case fatality rate; a significant proportion of cases result in death; prevalence may be lower than incidence

Mortality < Incidence

Lower case fatality rate; a significant proportion of cases survive; prevalence may be higher than incidence

Mortality = Incidence

Steady state in the population; number of new cases balances the number of deaths; prevalence remains relatively stable
